Visa requirements for Romanian citizens

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to: navigation, search

Visa requirements for Romanian citizens are administrative entry restrictions by the authorities of other states placed on citizens of Romania. In 2014, Romanian citizens had visa-free or visa on arrival access to 148 countries and territories, ranking the Romanian passport 19th in the world (second lowest ranking of all EU member states; Croatia has the lowest ranking of all EU member states).[1]

Community for Democracy and Rights of Nations[edit]

Country/territory Conditions of access using a Romanian passport Length of stay permitted Fee (if applicable) Access using a Romanian identity card
 Abkhazia entry permit letter will be sent to e-mail, after e-mailing documents to visa@mfaapsny.org
exit permit will be issued by Monistry of Foreign Affairsd[94][95]
entering from Georgia can be difficult, but possible; expect: long waiting, interrogation, police guards will try to convince you to return
minimal checkings at the border with Russiae		 10/30 days/1 year (single entry)
3 months/1 year (multiple entry)		 10/20/30 US dollars (single entry)
40/60 US dollars (multiple entry)
payable on arrival in Sukhumi		 passport required
 Nagorno-Karabakh Republic visa on arrival (from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Stepanakert)f[96][97][98]
pre-arrival visa from NKR Permanent Mission to the Republic of Armenia required if entering Saturday or Sunday when the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is closed
minimal checkings at the border with Armenia
border with Azerbaijan is closed; no crossing points with Iran		 single entry: 21 days/1/2/3 months
multi-entry: 1/2/3 months		 single entry: 3.000/24.000/30.000/36.000 Armenian Drams
multi-entry: 33.000/39.000/44.000 Armenian Drams		 passport required
 South Ossetia migration card issued on arrival, email must be sent 3 days in advance to mfa-rso@mail.ru
the migration card must be registered in Tskhinvali; ask the hotel officials to register you
border with Georgia is closed; obtain a multi-entry visa to Russia, enter and exit from/to Russia[99][100]		 unknown n/a passport required
 Transnistria no visa required[101] 24 hours without registrationg n/a passport required

d. ^ The pre-arrival visa is a free Entry Permit Letter, obtained by e-mail request. The permit allows only the entrance. While in Abkhazia, visit the Consular Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Abkhazia, in Sukhumi, to obtain the actual visa which will serve as an exit permit document.
e. ^ If entering from Russia, do not exit to Georgia, because you will be subject to punishment and fines by Georgian customs. By Georgian law, crossing the Russian-Abkhazian border is considered a violation of the Georgian border regime (an illegal entry to Georgia), whereas Georgia doesn't recognize Abkhazia and considers it a part of its territory. From the Georgian law point of view, a legal travel into Abkhazia must be originated and ended in Georgia. Entering Abkhazia from Georgia and exiting by land to Russia (or by air or sea to another country) will be considered an illegal exit of Georgia. Try not to enter Georgia with a passport used to travel to Abkhazia by entering from Russia and then exiting back to Russia, or by entering from Georgia and then exiting to Russia.
f. Visas can be obtained only from Nagorno-Karabakh Republic's Permanent Mission in Armenia. Request consular or border officials to issue the visa or entry/exit stamps on a separate piece of paper, otherwise you won't be able to travel to Azerbaijan with that passport. Azerbaijan considers Nagorno-Karabakh Republic part of its territory and will revoke visa, turn away, deport or even arrest anyone who attempts to enter the country with a Karabakh visa and entry/exit stamp in his passport.
g. ^ Visitors intending to stay in Transnistria more than 24 hous must register with the local police (fee: 2 US Dollars).

Passport validity[edit]

A Romanian passport

at least 1 year[edit]

In this particular case, some sources say 1 year, some sources say 6 months. To avoid complications, it is best to use a pssport with the longer time mentioned.

  •  Democratic Republic of the Congo

  •  Angola

Vaccination[edit]

Many African countries, including Angola, Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Republic of the Congo, Côte d'Ivoire, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Ghana, Guinea, Liberia, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Rwanda, São Tomé and Príncipe, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Uganda, Zambia require all incoming passengers to have a current International Certificate of Vaccination. Some other countries require vaccination only if the passenger is coming from an infected area.[463]

Fingerprinting[edit]

Several countries including Argentina, Cambodia, Japan, Malaysia, Saudi Arabia, South Korea and the United States demand all passengers to be fingerprinted on arrival.[464][465][466][467][468][469][470]

Rejection of Romanian passports[edit]

Romanian passport is recognized by all the countries in the world. Albeit, in some rare cases, Romanian citizens might be refused entry. Most common situations are:

  • Evidence of travel to Israel or Nagorno-Karabakh Republic
  • Armenian name or ancestry
  • Persona non grata

Failure of meeting the criteria required on entrance by a specific country/territory is not an act of rejection of the Romanian passport as a document issued by the Romanian authorities.

Evidence of travel to Israel[edit]

Visitors with passport stamp or visa of Israel are not allowed to enter the following countries:[471][472][473][474][475][476][477][478][479][480]

  •  Algeria
  •  Iran
  •  Iraq
  •  Kuwait
  •  Lebanon
  •  Libya
  •  Oman
  •  Qatar
  •  Sudan
  •  Syria
  •  Saudi Arabia
  •  Yemen

Entering Israel by air seems the best option to avoid evidence of travel to Israel in the passport. The border guards from Ben Gurion Airport in Tel Aviv no longer stamp the passport, instead they issue a small pieces of blue paper that stand for the stay permit and entry stamp and a similar piece or pink paper that stands for exit permit and exit stamp. Entering and leaving Israel by air leaves no evidence of travel there in the passport.

Some border guards of the above countries might take the time to search the passport for evidence of travel to Israel such as entry stamps of Egypt or Jordan from land crossing points on their border with Israel or Palestine. The Egyptian or Jordanian entry stamp from the Egyptian-Israeli border or the Jordanian-Israeli border will be considered evidence of travel to Israel and access will be denied with that specific passport.

Evidence of travel to Nagorno-Karabakh Republic[edit]

Visitors with passport stamp and visa of the Nagorno-Karabakh Republic are not allowed to enter the following country:

  •  Azerbaijan

As a result of the Nagorno-Karabakh War between Azerbaijan and Armenia, Azerbaijan refuses entry to foreigners in general whose passport shows evidence of entry into the self-proclaimed Nagorno-Karabakh Republic, immediately declaring them permanent personae non gratae.[76]

At request, the Karabakh authorities may attach the visa to a separate piece of paper in order to avoid detection of travel to their country.

Armenian name or ancestry[edit]

Azerbaijan authorities refuse entry to passport-holders of Romania and any other country if they have Armenian name or are of Armenian descent.

Persona non grata[edit]

The government of a country can declare a Romanian diplomat persona non grata, banning their access into the country. In non-diplomatic use, the authorities of a foreign country may declare a Romanian citizen persona non grata permanently or temporarily, usually because of unlawful activity. Attempts to enter the Gaza strip by sea may attract a 10 year-ban on entering Israel.[225]

Non-ordinary passports[edit]

Holders of various categories of official Romanian passports have additional visa-free access to the following countries:

  •  Algeria: diplomatic or service passports
  •  Azerbaijan: diplomatic or service passports
  •  Belarus: diplomatic or service passports
  •  People's Republic of China: diplomatic or service passports
  •  Ghana: diplomatic, official or service passports
  •  India: diplomatic passports
  •  Iran: diplomatic passports
  •  Kazakhstan: diplomatic or service passports
  •  Mongolia: diplomatic or official passports
  •  Pakistan: diplomatic or official passports
  •  Russia: diplomatic and service passports
  •  South Africa: diplomatic, official or service passports
  •  Tajikistan: diplomatic or service passports
  •  Thailand: diplomatic or official passports
  •  Turkmenistan: diplomatic or service passports
  •  Uzbekistan: diplomatic, official or service passports
  •  Vietnam: (diplomatic or service passports)

Holders of diplomatic or service passports of any country have visa-free access to Cape Verde, Ethiopia, Mali and Zimbabwe.

Caribbean:  Cuba,  Puerto Rico (US),  United States Virgin Islands (US).

South America:  Guyana,  Suriname.

Oceania:  American Samoa (US),  Guam (US),  Northern Mariana Islands (US),  Tokelau (NZ).

  • 40 territories are accessible with a special permit:

Europe: Jan Mayen (Nor.), Mount Athos (Gre.).

Africa:  Ascension Island (part of  Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha, UK), Darfur (provinces of Sudan), Hala'ib Triangle (annexed by Egypt, claimed by Sudan),  Tristan da Cunha (part of  Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha, UK).

Asia: Andaman and Nicobar Islands (Ind.), Arunachal Pradesh (Ind.), Azad Jammu and Kashmir (Pak.),  British Indian Ocean Territory (UK), Gaza Strip (Hamas controlled territory of Palestine), Ghajar (city split between Lebanon and Israeli controlled Golan Heights), Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Province (Taj.), Korean Demilitarized Zone (jointly controlled by United Nations, North Korea and South Korea), Lakshadweep (Ind.), Sikkim (Ind.), Tibet Autonomous Region (Chi.), UNDOF Zone (UNIFIL controlled territory).

Caribbean: Navassa Island (US).

South America:  South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands (UK).

Oceania: Ashmore and Cartier Islands (Aus.), Baker Island (US), Clipperton Island (Fr.), Howland Island (US), Jarvis Island (US), Kermadec Islands (NZ), Kingman Reef (US), Midway Atoll (US), Palmyra Atoll (US).

Antarctica: Adélie Land (part of  French Southern and Antarctic Lands, Fr.),  Argentine Antarctica (Arg)., Australian Antarctic Territory (Aus).,  British Antarctic Territory (UK), Chilean Antarctic Territory (Chile), Heard Island and McDonald Islands (Aus.), Kerguelen-St. Paul-Amsterdam-Crozet islands (main islands of  French Southern and Antarctic Lands, Fr.), Peter I Island (Nor)., Queen Maud Land (Nor.), Ross Dependency (NZ), Scattered Islands in the Indian Ocean (part of  French Southern and Antarctic Lands, Fr.).

Conditions unclear[edit]

Legally unclear or undefined access conditions in 5 countries or territories:

Europe:  Federal State of Novorossiya.

Africa: Al-Shabaab controlled areas of Somalia, Buffer Zone in Western Sahara (controlled by MINURSO), La Güera enclave (de jure: Polisario Front controlled territory; de facto: guarded by a Mauritanian military outpost),  Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic (Polisario Front controlled territory).

No access[edit]

Restricted access to 4 territories:

  • 3 territories are restricted to access (military facilities)

Caribbean: Guantanamo Bay Naval Base (US).

Oceania: Johnston Atoll (US), Wake Island (US).

  • 1 territory has no legal crossing points:

Africa: Bir Tawil (not claimed by neither Egypt nor Sudan, de jure part of Egypt)

ID card travel[edit]

Romanian citizens without a passport can travel ONLY with their identity card in 61 countries or territories.

Europe:  Albania,  Austria,  Åland Islands (Fin.),  Andorra,  Azores (Port.),  Belgium,  Bosnia and Herzegovina,  Bulgaria,  Croatia,  Cyprus,  Czech Republic,  Denmark,  Estonia,  Faroe Islands (Den.),  Finland,  France,  Georgia,  Germany,  Gibraltar (UK),  Greece,  Guernsey (UK),  Hungary,  Ireland,  Isle of Man (UK),  Italy,  Jersey (UK),  Kosovo,  Latvia,  Liechtenstein,  Lithuania,  Luxembourg,  Macedonia,  Malta,  Monaco,  Montenegro,  Netherlands,  Norway (only ID cards issued after 2009),  Poland,  Portugal,  San Marino,  Serbia,  Slovakia,  Slovenia, Sovereign Base Areas of Akrotiri and Dhekelia (UK),  Sovereign Military Order of Malta,  Spain,  Svalbard (Nor.; only ID cards issued after 2009),  Sweden,   Switzerland,  Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus,  United Kingdom,   Vatican City.

Africa:  Canary Islands (Sp.),  Ceuta (Sp.),  Madeira (Port.),  Melilla (Sp.),  Réunion (Fr.).

Caribbean:  Guadeloupe (Fr.),  Martinique (Fr.).

Antarctica:  Bouvet Island (Nor.), Marie Byrd Land (unclaimed by any sovereign nation).

Right to consular protection in non-EU countries[edit]

When in a non-EU country where there is no Romanian embassy, Romanian citizens as EU citizens have the right to get consular protection from the embassy of any other EU country present in that country.

1 British Overseas Territories. 2 Open border with Schengen Area. 3 Russia is a transcontinental country in Eastern Europe and Northern Asia. The vast majority of its population (80%) lives in European Russia, therefore Russia as a whole is included as a European country here. 4 Turkey is a transcontinental country in the Middle East and Southeast Europe. Has a small part of its territory (3%) in Southeast Europe called Turkish Thrace. 5 Azerbaijan and Georgia (Abkhazia; South Ossetia) are transcontinental countries. Both have a small part of their territories in the European part of the Caucasus. 6 Kazakhstan is a transcontinental country. Has a small part of its territories located west of the Urals in Eastern Europe. 7 Armenia (Nagorno-Karabakh) and Cyprus (Northern Cyprus; Akrotiri and Dhekelia) are entirely in Southwest Asia but having socio-political connections with Europe. 8 Egypt is a transcontinental country in North Africa and the Middle East. Has a small part of its territory in the Middle East called Sinai peninsula. 9 Part of the Realm of New Zealand. 10 Partially recognized.
